name: Siberian Ginseng
summary: Siberian ginseng (Eleutherococcus senticosus) is an adaptogenic herb traditionally used to enhance resilience to stress, support energy, and strengthen immune function.
description: Siberian ginseng, also known as Eleuthero, is a woody shrub native to Northeast Asia and long used in traditional Chinese and Russian medicine as an adaptogen. Unlike true Panax ginseng, Siberian ginseng contains eleutherosides rather than ginsenosides. These compounds are thought to modulate the stress response, enhance physical stamina, and support immune activity. It has been studied for its potential to improve mental performance under stress, reduce fatigue, and support recovery from illness. Evidence in psychiatric and integrative medicine suggests possible benefits for resilience, cognitive performance, and mood stabilization, though high-quality data are limited.

metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for therapeutic indications)

off_label_uses: Adjunctive support for cognitive performance under stress

items: Supports resilience to physical and mental stress
Helps reduce fatigue and enhance energy
May improve mental performance under fatigue

sections.text: Siberian ginseng contains eleutherosides, compounds thought to influence the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis and stress hormone regulation. It may enhance cellular energy production, support immune modulation, and improve resilience to physical and psychological stressors.

adult.typical: 300–1200 mg/day of standardized extract divided into 2–3 doses
adult.note: Often used for 6–8 weeks followed by a break to prevent tolerance.

sections.pediatric: Not routinely recommended outside supervised clinical use.

sections.text: Effects on energy and stress resilience may appear within 1–2 weeks; immune and adaptogenic benefits develop with longer-term use.

serious: Hypertensive crisis (rare, with very high doses or in uncontrolled hypertension)

other: Avoid in individuals with uncontrolled high blood pressure or arrhythmias.
May cause overstimulation or insomnia if taken late in the day.
Not recommended in pregnancy or lactation due to insufficient safety data.

sections.pediatrics: Not typically used outside clinical trials

sections.text: No tapering required, but cycling use (e.g., breaks after 6–8 weeks) is advised.

items: Not a true ginseng; differs from Panax ginseng in phytochemistry and pharmacology.
Used in traditional Russian medicine for enhancing stamina in athletes and workers.
Evidence base is moderate; better-studied for fatigue and resilience than for psychiatric outcomes.
